title: Deutsche Mark
summary: The Deutsche Mark (German: [ˈdɔʏtʃə ˈmaʁk] (listen), "German mark"), abbreviated "DM" or "D-Mark" ([ˈdeːˌmaʁk] (listen)), was the official currency of West Germany from 1948 until 1990 and later the unified Germany from 1990 until the adoption of the euro in 2002. In English, it is commonly called the "Deutschmark" (/ˈdɔɪtʃmɑːrk/); this expression is unknown in Germany. The Germans usually called it D-Mark when referring to the currency, and Mark when talking about individual sums. One Deutsche Mark was divided into 100 pfennigs.
